summary: A depressed man (Edward Norton) suffering from insomnia meets a strange soap salesman named Tyler Durden (Brad Pitt) and soon finds himself living in his squalid house after his perfect apartment is destroyed. The two bored men form an underground club with strict rules and fight other men who are fed up with their mundane lives. Their perfect partnership frays when Marla (Helena Bonham Carter), a fellow support group crasher, attracts Tyler's attention.

reviews.content: Masterpiece. I could rewatch it 1000 times.

Finally watched this classic after years of being admonished by people who consider it one of their favorite films. It was fast paced, intense, and undoubtedly entertaining. The truth is, without Brad Pitt and Edward Norton's nuanced performances, this film wouldn't have impressed me all that much. I imagine that in 1999, it would have had much more bite than in 2023, a time in which we've all become so accustomed to edgy, mind f*** type media. 

I can see how some get the idea that the film glorifies violence and hyper-masculine bravado. I viewed it as more of a cautionary tale of a man who doesn't appreciate his life  and thinks violence will be his salvation, only to find that it's an ever-escalating road to nowhere and what he truly wanted could have been his all along. 

At any rate, it's a film worth watching if only for the iconic performances and slick visuals.

Fight Club is a provocative and thought-provoking film that challenges viewers to question the values and norms of modern society. Directed by David Fincher and based on the novel by Chuck Palahniuk, Fight Club is a movie that rewards repeated viewings, as it is filled with subtle details and layered meanings that are easy to miss on first viewing.

The film stars Brad Pitt as Tyler Durden, a charismatic and enigmatic figure who leads the narrator, played by Edward Norton, into a world of violent rebellion against the consumerist culture that surrounds them. The two form a "fight club," a secret organization where men gather to physically fight each other as a way of releasing pent-up frustration and aggression.

While the film's violent content has drawn criticism, it is ultimately a commentary on the destructive nature of masculinity in modern society. The characters in the film are struggling to find meaning and purpose in their lives, and their violent behavior is a manifestation of their frustration and sense of powerlessness in the face of societal pressures.

Fight Club is also notable for its stunning visual style, which combines a gritty, urban aesthetic with surreal and dreamlike imagery. The film's use of subliminal messages and fourth-wall-breaking techniques add to its unsettling and thought-provoking nature.

However, Fight Club is not a movie for everyone. Its themes and content can be challenging and disturbing, and some viewers may find its message to be nihilistic or even dangerous. Nevertheless, for those who are willing to engage with its ideas and wrestle with its complexities, Fight Club is a powerful and unforgettable cinematic experience that raises important questions about the nature of identity, masculinity, and the pursuit of happiness in a modern world.

I'm torn on this one. On one hand, I love a lot of the movie - the grimy look, the performances by Norton and Pitt, the comedy, and the mystery. On the other hand, I don't like the ending, it's less interesting than the setup and too large in scale – I think almost all the movie's strongest scenes have very limited settings and relatively few characters. There is also some interesting social commentary at play. The criticism of capitalism is interwoven nicely into the narrative, though it's also tied to the ending which I found too fantastical and out of touch with the rest of the movie. I did like the theme of masculinity in the film though.

The bold and edgy movie "Fight Club" examines issues of masculinity, capitalism, and the human mind. Brad Pitt, Edward Norton, and Helena Bonham Carter play the main characters in David Fincher's film, which also features other notable actors. 

The narrative centres on Jack, an office worker who struggles to find meaning and purpose in his life and suffers from insomnia (played by Norton). When Jack eventually meets Tyler Durden (Pitt), he is introduced to the world of underground fighting clubs by this charismatic and enigmatic man. Jack and Tyler work together to create a cult-like movement that seeks to upend the status quo of society and implement extreme change.

It takes several viewings of the movie "Fight Club" to completely grasp its complex plot and challenging ideas. Dark and dirty visuals complement the film's nonlinear story, which keeps viewers guessing until the very end. 

Pitt and Norton both give amazing performances, and their on-screen chemistry is fantastic. Strong performances from the supporting ensemble, which includes Bonham Carter, complete the characters played by the leading performers. 

Despite the fact that "Fight Club" contains violent and explicit sequences, the movie is unquestionably a unique and thought-provoking work of cinema. Overall, if you're seeking for a smart, suspenseful thriller that questions the social order, I definitely suggest this film.

David Fincher's Fight Club is a decent enough movie, but it might also be one of the most overrated films of all time, a sporadically fascinating and sporadically pretentious statement about how capitalism and consumerism crushes individuality.  The story is brutal but always interesting, the cinematography is excellent, Fincher's direction (especially some of the camera angles he chooses) is inspired at times, the score is fantastic, and the acting is great throughout.  Where the film falters at times is in its stylistic excesses, most of which feel inconsistent and unnecessary – the breaking of the fourth wall, the rapid-fire editing, the single-frame subliminal shots, and much more.  It's a good movie with an important message, but it's really not a great movie.

One aspect of the film that makes this movie stand out is the personality differences between the two main characters. The first main character who we follow throughout the film (who is unnamed) is the average white-collar worker who tends to keep to himself while Tyler Durden is almost the complete opposite and is super energetic and outgoing but has a mysterious vibe to him. Unlike the first main character, he has multiple jobs but his main job is being a soap salesman. The movie's settings and environments add to their personality differences. It starts with where you would think an office worker would live, in a bustling city. Then we move to an abandoned house on the outskirts of the city next to a factory where nobody is living in the vicinity and you have the freedom to do whatever you want, representing Tyler Durden's character completely.
This film had its moments and I would say that it was an above-average film. There were times when it had you up off your seat and not knowing what would happen next while there were times when the storyline got so convoluted that I didn't even know what was going on. A lot of the time, this movie leaves you wondering what the point of this scene is. Some scenes don't add anything to the story and end up confusing it even more. If you can get past the confusingness of the story, the focus on mental health and society shines throughout most of the movie but is somewhat ruined by the twisting and confusing plot. I would recommend this move to a more mature audience that can handle themes of violence and mental health issues. A pretty good movie but nothing special.

	After watching the film Fight Club by David Fincher, I think that the film's quality was not the best, but it was very great. The film's production with special effects and the plot of the story was amazing. The plot of the story had very many ups and downs, not ups and downs as the quality, but the pace of the story. There were many moments where we dove into different characters like Tyler and Edward. Both of them were focused a lot throughout the film, but near the end these characters really were shown without any mask to hide behind. It seemed as if there was a fight between good vs evil, yet they were the same person with two different personas. I would not recommend this to a younger audience because of how complex the story is and the use of many things, like sex, drugs, and mental illness. Overall I would rate the movie 4.3 / 5 stars. The film was amazing, but there can be some improvements to the film whether it was more visuals or even a deeper dive into some side characters that had importance to the film.

Perhaps a little too long, but Fight Club is just a very well-made, brilliantly written and superlatively performed film. Essentially a satirical fable, it tells of an insomniac loser teaming up with a seditious soap salesman to form a no-holds-barred-fight club as an outlet for their direction-less aggression. This concept is an intriguing and original one, and works really well. Then there is the script, it is absolutely superb, with dialogue that will make you both laugh and think. Fight Club is very well made, with elaborate production design, great editing and startling images. David Fincher's direction is brilliantly handled and the performances of Edward Norton and Brad Pitt are superb. Overall, just a great film, a mesmerising ride through the 1990s male psyche. 9/10 Bethany Cox

"Fight Club" is an amazing film and dare I say one of my personal modern favorites, that delivers both a stunning and atmospheric look into the mind of an insomniac and his hallucinations.  Edward Norton plays the "Narrator" who can't sleep and is depressed when he goes to his doctor he is turned away and told to take some natural remedies for his insomnia.  It's around this time that he meets Tyler Durden (Brad Pitt) and his life takes a dramatic plunge into darkness and insanity!  The film is an intimate look into the life of the narrator and is filled with symbolism and complex dialogue and themes making it what many consider a masterpiece.  While I have viewed the film several times before, all these occurred when I was alone and not with a diverse and easily offended crowd.  While I always pick up various subtitle pieces and visuals or meaning with each viewing, It was hindered by the more sensitive of the crowd (There were eight of us total watching the film in our vacation log cabin at night time) who constantly let it be known that they were upset and that the film was terrible.  While of course I and most critics would argue the opposite, it is their opinion and they are entitled to it, no matter how versed in film they are.  The direction is superb as is the dialogue and set pieces, the acting from the leads is stunning and pulls you into their madness and adds up to a revelation!  "Fight Club" is Highly Recommended if you can stomach fighting and a dark and at times disturbing film that has many things to say!
